Utterance: <sync>
Hi, it's Ellie again. I'm glad to see you back today. How have you been since our last session?
I've been okay, I guess. A mix of ups and downs, like I mentioned last time.
That sounds familiar. Have there been any particular moments that stood out to you in the past week?
Yeah, actually. I had a really good day with friends, but then I also had a rough day where I felt really low.
I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me more about the low day?
Um, I just felt really unmotivated. I didn't want to do anything, and I ended up just sitting around all day.
What do you think triggered that feeling?
I think it was just a lot of pressure from school and feeling like I'm not doing enough.
That sounds tough. How do you usually cope with that kind of pressure?
I try to write or play music, but sometimes I just end up shutting down.
It makes sense that when you're feeling overwhelmed, it can be hard to engage in those activities that usually help. Have you tried any specific strategies when you feel that way?
Not really. I just kind of let it pass.
That’s understandable. Would you be open to exploring some coping techniques together today?
Sure, I’d be interested in that.
Great! One technique we can try is mindfulness. Have you ever practiced mindfulness or meditation before?
I've heard of it, but I haven't really tried it.
Mindfulness can help you stay grounded and manage those overwhelming feelings. Would you like to try a short exercise with me now?
Okay, I’m willing to give it a shot.
Awesome. Let’s start by taking a deep breath in together... and out. Focus on the sensation of your breath. What do you notice?
I feel a little more relaxed, actually.
That’s great to hear! The goal is to bring your attention back to your breath whenever your mind starts to wander. How do you feel about practicing this a few times a week?
I think I could try that.
Perfect. It can be a simple five-minute exercise. Now, thinking about your feelings of pressure, can you identify any specific areas where you feel you’re not doing enough?
Mostly in school. I feel like I should be getting better grades or doing more extracurricular activities.
It sounds like you have high expectations for yourself. What do you think drives those expectations?
I guess I just want to prove to myself and my family that I can succeed.
That’s understandable. Do you feel like those expectations are realistic?
Sometimes I feel like they’re too high, but then I also feel guilty for not meeting them.
It's common to feel that way. It might be helpful to reframe those expectations. What would it look like to set more achievable goals for yourself?
Maybe just focusing on one assignment at a time instead of trying to do everything at once.
That sounds like a constructive approach. How would you feel about setting a specific goal for this week related to your studies?
I could aim to finish my essay by the end of the week instead of stressing about all my assignments.
That sounds like a solid plan. How can you hold yourself accountable for that goal?
I could tell my friends about it, so they can check in on me.
That’s a great idea! Sharing your goals with others can provide additional motivation. How do you feel about your relationships with your friends?
They’re pretty good. They understand me, and I can talk to them about stuff.
That's wonderful. It sounds like you have a supportive network. Have you talked to them about how you’ve been feeling lately?
Not really. I tend to keep that stuff to myself.
Would you feel comfortable sharing your feelings with a close friend?
I think I could try. It might help to talk about it.
Absolutely. Opening up can often lighten the burden. What else do you think might help you navigate these ups and downs?
Maybe just being kinder to myself when I feel low instead of pushing myself to be okay.
That’s a powerful insight. Self-compassion can be a game changer. How can you practice that self-kindness this week?
I could remind myself that it’s okay to have bad days and that I don’t have to be perfect.
Exactly. It’s all part of being human. I’m really proud of you for recognizing that. Let’s check in on this in our next session. Does that sound good?
Yeah, that sounds great. Thank you, Ellie.
You’re welcome! I look forward to hearing how it goes. Take care!
